proportionally and then especially like in the 70s and ' 880s uh psychologist

this change here and then you can make a causal
conclusion right that's kind of the basic for AB testing right that's the
process behind it we have this super noisy data and we've copied that process
from science where we just say okay if we have all these external factors we do this randomization thing and then if
things go well we should be able to detect the change that our kind of tiny manipulation to the product or the
service or whatever creates and more technically that looks like this we take our user population or
a subset of that population with a randomization function that splits that into two three four five six groups and
then it's important that we have this control group where we don't do anything we just leave them be and we have our test groups where we apply some
change then we observe those groups and obviously kind of we try to measure the same thing across everyone so you can't
look at click through rate on this left group and then on retention on that group that would make any sense we look at the same thing for everyone and if
there's a difference between those groups then we can conclude yes that must be because we change
something so in order to do that you need a enough participants um so usually
kind of the common wisdom is that unless you have at least 7 8 9,000 AC users
like this doesn't really pay off you need a way to randomly assign them some
hashing algorithm or whatever you this is where things get

it's not cheap and easy to change your product and build kind of these um these
